isis.stitle: REPAIR INSTRUCTIONS FOR FIBERGLASS AND PLASTIC (ABS) MATERIAL - PLASTIC (ABS) - REPAIR TECHNIQUES

svcsubproc.title: Solvent Cement
svcsubproc.para: Intended for use in repairing deep scratches, nicks and small holes (less than 1/4 inch (6 mm) diameter).

note.para: Solvent cements are not recommended for use on high stressed areas or thin walled panels.

step1.para: Dissolve ABS pellets in a solvent such as Methyl Ethyl Keytone (MEK) or Methylene Chloride (MCL). The pellets are added to the solvent until a paste-like consistency is obtained.
Apply mixture to the prepared damaged area with a squeeze bottle and putty knife, spatula, trowel or similar applicator ( Figure 55).

figure.caption: Figure 55. Apply Mixture to Prepared Damaged Area

step1.para: After the solvent has evaporated, the hard material remaining can be shaped to the surface contour by filing and sanding.

svcsubproc.title: Hot Air Weld Technique
svcsubproc.para: Intended for use when repairing damage to thin walled panels, small holes or cracks in the surface where high stress is apparent.

step1.para: Hot weld adhesive is supplied in the form of ABS rods and can be applied directly to the damaged area with a hot air gun. The hot air gun and ABS rods are available through automotive equipment suppliers.

Weld the adhesive into the damaged area ( Figure 56). The hot air gun should be held to direct the flow of hot air equally into the damaged area and to the welding rod at the same time. The heat gun should be moved constantly in a fanning motion along the weld to prevent discoloration of the surrounding area. Enough pressure must be applied to the rod to insure good adhesion.

figure.caption: Figure 56. Weld Adhesive into Damaged Area

important.para: Be careful not to overheat the surface of the damaged area. If the heat gun is held too closely to the surface, or it remains aimed at a small area, the surface can become discolored.

svcsubproc.title: Hot Melt Technique
svcsubproc.para: Intended for use in repairing deep scratches and nicks.

note.para: Hot melt adhesives are not intended for use in areas of high stress due to their low strength.

step1.para: Hot melt adhesive polyamids (rods) are supplied in stick form, 1/2 inch (13 mm) in diameter by 3 inches (76 mm) in length, and can be applied directly to the prepared damaged area with a hot air gun (refer to ( Figure 57).

figure.caption: Figure 57. Apply Hot Melt Adhesive Polyamids to Prepared Damaged Area

important.para: Be careful not to overheat the surface of the damaged area. If the heat gun is held too closely to the surface, or it remains aimed at a small area, the surface can become discolored.

step1.para: After the repair is completed and the repaired area has cooled, the patch may be shaped to the surface contour by filing and sanding.
